This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Coming to attend this talk, I'm Paul Coggin from Huntsville, Alabama, in the U.S.
This is my fourth time speaking at X33FCon.
I sincerely appreciate the invitation to return.
I came in to Poland a few days early and got to visit SOPOD and Gdansk.
I love this country.
It is so beautiful.
The Baltic Sea area is just breathtaking, fabulous people, great food.
I love to eat and I ate a lot while I was here.
It's been a really, really great visit and a fun time being back here in Poland again.
So this talk, I'm going to get into some ideas around threat hunting for both space and digital
energy.
The genesis of this talk, years ago, when I first started thinking about this subject,
my kids were making me watch the Transformers movie over and over and over.
And being an IT computer security nerd, I was thinking, you know, how would someone
detect a sophisticated attack like the Decepticons, where they're embedded themselves like in
a satellite or the Air Force One and the other computer systems that were getting attacked.
They were so hard to detect what they were doing, how they got in, et cetera.
And around that same time, there was all the activity in the news around the Stuxnet attack
against the centrifuges in the Iran nuclear program.
So I was starting to really, it was puzzling me, how would we go and detect these sophisticated
attacks?
That the normal IT security monitoring is not detecting and is missing.
My initial thoughts, being an old school network guy, because I come from a background, basically
network engineering.
I came up through telco service provider enterprise networking.
So I was always thinking about, you know, as an old school router guy, how would we
go and attack this and detect it?
And so I started thinking about in-band and out-of-band data management, collecting all
the logs, both in-band and out-of-band, and correlating the logs, looking for differences
from the environment, et cetera.
But as my thoughts matured more, I started realizing, you know, that's not enough, need
to go deeper.
And so I spent a lot of my career also working in smart grid, industrial control systems,
data.
Now everybody calls it operational technology, internet of things, et cetera, whatever the
marketing buzzword that the vendors are selling this week.
But brought me back to this Purdue model to describe how to maybe look at some of these
problems differently that are being missed in the critical infrastructure and some of
the large enterprises.
And that's going down to the lower level, down to the physical systems, looking at things
like electrical signals to different sensors, vibration, actuators, measuring current draw,
get as low level as we can out-of-band so that there's no external influences to this
data.
But go down as low as we can and monitor the signaling that's happening, and then correlate
that with the whole system of system of the normal data that we usually collect with our
logging systems to get an idea of what's happening.
So this presentation is a lot of brainstorming that I did on what are all the data sources
that those typical network and IT professionals may be missing that are out there.
And I'll tell you one thing I've learned from some of the professionals that are true experts
in industrial control systems and SCADA is there's not a lot of security down here at
level zero, level one in those devices, not a lot of authentication happening.
It's a pretty insecure, it's a pretty unsecure environment when you get down to those levels.
There's standards that are being worked on it for level zero, level one, but it's not,
most places it's not there yet.
One thing is I was making sure that I was not totally off track, I went and looked at
the MITRE ATT&CK, and they have 39 data sources identified, and again, some of what I've kind
of confirmed to myself is that going and drilling down in the physics-based data sources may
be a place that's being overlooked that we should go look at as cybersecurity professionals
that are trying to find the decepticons in the network, the proverbial APT that is so
hard to find.
So a lot of the inspiration I got to go back and revisit this is I'm working on my fourth
master's in space systems, which is basically physics, and as I was digging into all this
physics for the space systems, academic work I'm doing, I said, you know, how would these
physicists go about attacking the problem?
Because the way that I think about it, and you know, a lot of peers in the network industry,
we're obviously missing something, so how, you know, how would the physicists go about
it, and what would Newton and Einstein do?
How would they think about it?
So one example of a sensor, low-cost sensor, if we were in a critical infrastructure environment,
maybe go and look at something like a vibration sensor to collect logging information from.
They like those, for example, those Iranian centrifuges back in the day when they were
spinning and the current was fluctuating, the centrifuge, the speed was changing in
those centrifuges, there's probably was some vibration, there's probably some current draw
changes, and if there was like a vibration sensor on that, maybe that would have detected
it.
So also maybe some of our other critical infrastructure environments, maybe a gas pipeline, what
have you, maybe if we had a vibration sensor monitoring those critical infrastructure networks,
maybe that would give the security monitoring team, the threat hunting team, some new key
data.
Something I found a real interesting idea is acoustic monitoring.
You could monitor the acoustics of, say, the pipes, and listen for different variations
in the sounds that you're hearing in, say, your pipes.
Also in power transformers, there's a lot of talk about the power grid being a target
for nation-state entities that the critical infrastructure is going to be targeted, the
power grid obviously is a big target.
Well, what about looking at power transformers?
Apparently, I'm not an electrical engineer, I don't work in the power industry, but apparently
some of the power transformers have oil in them, and it is a good point of data source
to listen to the sound, the harmonics of the transformers that are filled with oil, because
apparently they'll make different noises, and then you could either maybe predict a
maintenance issue, you could forecast, hey, we need to be prepared to replace a transformer
that's starting to fail, or it could be an indicator or a threat hunt team that works
for that power grid provider, hey, we may have somebody helping us manage the network,
we might need to go and investigate this further, both with a maintenance team and with cyber
SMEs to correlate this data to make sure that it's not a maintenance problem, or we have
a sophisticated attack against our power transformer.
So, it's another good data indicator to look at.
Harmonics from the current, apparently you can, it's possible to study the current that
is being drawn by computer systems and detect the software that's being run.
Maybe that is a way to consider for threat hunt teams to be able to detect malware that
is running on targeted systems and key critical infrastructure, to detect software that we're
not aware of, that's wholly outside of configuration management and control, something that's not
in our inventory, maybe monitoring the harmonics and baselining that out of the current utilization
is a new indicator that if we correlated the whole big system of systems into our logs
and applied like machine learning to it and baselined that, we could find that anomaly,
that needle in the haystack, by looking at this harmonics metric.
And this was really fascinating to me as a physics-based data source, everyone is talking
about PNT in the news, I follow a lot of industry experts in the space industry, and they talk
about the timing, GPS, GNSS, all the timing sources with satellites.
I had, it's fascinating to me that the power grid is very dependent on timing to sync up
the timing between all the different transmission systems so that they can accurately reroute
power and if the timing is off, power starts getting routed the wrong way, bad things are
going to happen, it's going to cause, they could cause major interruptions in the grid
if timing is not totally synced up against the whole power grid system.
And a lot of the systems use NTP, network time protocol, might use GPS sensors to pull
accurate timing, but GPS can be spoofed, it's in the news regularly now that GPS is being
spoofed, so that can be targeted by jamming or spoofing.
And of course NTP, there's been some denial of service attacks against NTP, so we need
to go and look at backups for the GPS systems and NTP, the NTP is being moved to precision
timing protocol, it's more accurate, but there are other alternatives like the Celsium and
rubidium oscillators and some other satellites that we can monitor, but the threat hunting
team definitely needs to be monitoring the timing sources, wherever they're pulling that
timing sync from, need to be monitoring that for variations to make sure someone is not
targeting timing, trying to disrupt the power grid system or the network that they're monitoring.
This is a key place to go and monitor, because I know in my experience working with power
companies, everyone is working, everybody is doing what everybody does, monitor the
firewall logs, you're watching the server logs, your SCADA logs, your HMI logs, but
what about the power, making sure that power and putting logging capability to sync up
and keep an eye on your power, key thing not to lose sight of.
Again, going back to some of the satellite system attacks that we may be overlooking
like GPS, et cetera, is the satellite control system for the user segment that goes on ships.
There's been a lot of activity where from the satellite system that the communications
on the ships utilize for navigation, being able to talk back to the owners of the ships,
and there's typically an organization that will be managing ships or different organizations
that keep up with all the traffic routes and what's going on with the weather, et cetera.
Third party organizations, kind of like a knock sock for ships that is taking care of
all the logistics and management of the ships, they'll come in over SATCOMs to help the captains
manage the ship.
In many cases, the captains are responsible for the ship, but there's other organizations
that are telling the captains exactly what to do, where they're going to navigate, and
how to traverse the seas, make sure that they don't run aground or run into weather issues.
But it's showing here that coming in over those satellite links, the navigation systems
and all are being targeted.
So those systems need to be monitored.
All of the different physics-based navigation systems on the ship should be monitored to
make sure somebody hasn't come in over a SATCOM link and is helping us drive the ship.
In this case, there was a German ship that was headed to Djibouti over near Kenya off
the east coast of Africa, and the pirates had one of the ships hacked for like 10 hours,
had control of it and were steering it.
And also from the theme of this presentation about physics-based monitoring, it was released
that some classified data was released that the Iranians were researching how to make
a ship blow up.
That's going to go back to physics-based monitoring.
They're trying to go and figure out how to make something kinetic happen through a cyber
attack, say maybe blowing up a pump, making a centrifuge fail, maybe blowing up a pump
at a fuel station.
They need to put an emphasis on physics-based monitoring on these ships.
Another incident happened just a few years ago.
Apparently there was a ship coming out headed to New York that had gotten hacked and got
taken over, and the folks who targeted the ship had complete control of the navigational
system and were able to drive the ship.
Apparently, according to this Cyber Owl Consulting Company, they're saying that they're seeing
at least one attack against ships a day.
So those ships are getting targeted through the satellite communication system and down
into the navigational control system that drive the ship, and that's going to be a bunch
of physics-based devices, gyroscopes, et cetera, that are on those ships and should be getting
monitored, that we should be collecting data on to know what's happening with our ship,
not just monitoring the Windows server, but also monitoring those IOT, operational technology
devices on the ship.
There's been a great deal of talk about GPS spoofing, especially with the war going on
in Ukraine.
It's been going on for a long time, GPS spoofing.
It's in the news a great deal here recently.
In a lot of cases, what the GPS spoofing is doing that we're reading about is it's trying
to defeat drones.
If you can confuse the drones, you might be able to make a drone either land or return
back to base if it's getting outside of where it knows it's supposed to be.
If it's getting confused, it'll just fly back home.
You can get GPS receivers that are hardened, but those GPS receivers that are hardened
are not going to tell you who's attacking you.
If you want to set up the ability to identify where the attack is coming from, not just
try to protect the device, but also identify it, as threat hunters, you're going to need
to have additional antennas that can not only receive the signal, detect the signal that
the GPS is being targeted and protect, say, a ship or a UAV drone device from it, but
also you're going to need additional antennas to be able to detect the direction the attack
is coming from, if that is of interest to you.
Another physics-based source to consider, going back to ships, is the echo sounder.
That would be a good target for a terrorist organization because that echo sounder on
a ship is going to tell the ship how deep of water they're in, whether they're about
to go and maybe get up on a sandbar or a reef.
I've got an example here of a pristine reef that a ship doesn't know that it was about
to run aground, that it was off course for like four days until it ran up on a pristine reef.
So maybe somebody was messing with the navigation system and the nautical maps were not showing
that they were where they thought they were, as well as the echo sounder was not telling
them that they were starting to run into shallow water and run up on a reef.
So I'll have an example of that.
Another device to be looking at is the denominator for monitoring wind.
There is an issue in the Suez Canal not too long ago, there's a lot of speculation about
what happened there.
There is speculation that there was a couple pilots and the captains were maybe arguing
on the bridge about who had authority to drive the ship through the canal.
There's speculation that there was speculation about a cyber attack.
And there's also some thought that what might have happened is in that part of the world
where the Suez Canal is, it could have been wind.
My question is, so were the wind sensors being monitored or were they being influenced?
If it was a cyber attack, were they collecting the logs off those wind sensors?
Did they have a baseline of that to know what kind of anomaly might be happening?
But that was in the news for a long time there.
They had the whole canal blocked.
But that is a key instrument to also look at monitoring the health and status of, not
only for maintenance and making sure you're not experiencing issues due to the wind, but
also from a possible someone having a cyber security attack to influence the vessel.
Another device to consider for getting physics-based logs from is an accelerometer, where it's
a device that's going to measure acceleration.
So that mechanical motion is going to be turned into an electrical signal.
So as threat hunters, as cyber security professionals, it's our job to monitor these type of vessels,
whether it's a satellite or a ship, what have you.
We should maybe consider monitoring that mechanical to electrical signal that is being generated
and have that baselined and adding that to our logging and applying machine learning
to it over time so that we can detect those possible anomalies.
Or it could be, again, going back, it could be that we could proactively predict a maintenance
issue and deal with the problem before it turns into a really big expensive issue or
a possible catastrophe, because we're being proactive in monitoring.
Not every problem is a cyber attack, so it could be that it enables proactive maintenance.
If it is a cyber attack, we'll at least have maybe have an early warning.
Then we've got a gyroscope, very similar nature, where we're going to keep up with our orientation
and our speed.
We're going to have these on our space vehicle satellites, space station, also on ships,
whether it's a military ship or cruise ships, cargo ships, et cetera, they're going to have
gyroscopes.
That's going to be a key device to monitor and get instrumentation on for the threat
hunt team to know what's going on with that vessel to see if someone's influencing the
operation of the vehicle.
It could be on a drone as well.
Speaking of all these physics-based indicators on ships, there's a thing called a voyage
data recorder.
Voyage data recorder is kind of like a black box for ships, you know, you've got the black
box on planes.
Well, ships have something similar called the voyage data recorder.
My thought is, if I worked for a cruise line or if I worked for a military or some cargo
ship organization in the future, I would want to have a voyage data recorder for my network
cybersecurity team so that they're getting an independent, pristine copy of all the instrumentation
data from all the operational technology on that ship, the navigation system, the gyroscopes,
all the electrical, mechanical to electrical signaling that's happening on that ship.
I'd want to have my own voyage data recorder that my security operations center, my threat
hunters could be monitoring to pull independent, pristine logs to be able to figure if somebody's
helping me run my ship.
Because here is an example of this Waukeshio ship that ran aground, apparently, for four
days.
There were two monitoring systems.
There was the owners of the ship that monitored the ship, and then there's a third party that
monitors and manages ships for the owners.
And like I said, they work with the captains, and apparently, those organizations have more
control and authority than the captain on the ship about where the ship is going, the
speed, the direction they're taking based on weather, et cetera.
In both of those networks that are monitoring the health status, monitoring location of
those ships, apparently, they had bad data for four days, and nobody knew what really
was going on with that ship until it ran aground up on a pristine reef.
So that goes back to, from a threat hunting standpoint, as cybersecurity professionals,
we need to be able to have a voyage data recorder access of our own so that the threat hunters
can be pulling this data and correlating it with enterprise-type data to get a baseline
of what's happening with the network.
This goes back to where I've spent most of my years as a professional in telecommunications,
service provider networks, and I presented on this a few years ago, about four years
ago, about hacking telecommunications, service provider networks.
So since we're talking about physics-based detection, I wanted to bring this back up.
It's not talked a lot about, especially the telecommunications companies, they don't want
to talk about the fact that their networks get hacked like everybody else's do, and there's
insider threats, there's nation states that are targeting their networks, there's organized
crime that are targeting their networks as well, but we just treat it like the cloud.
It's a black box to us.
BGP is being hijacked.
If you're not aware of it, you need to be watching and monitoring your BGP, but also,
if you're buying services like multi-protocol label switching, which a lot of us in the
enterprise world treat as a black box network and we just don't ask any questions, the telco
tells us it's secure.
They use the acronym VPN, so everybody assumes that that implies encryption, but it doesn't.
It's just a layer two, layer three, unencrypted VPN.
It's not encrypted until you lay encryption on it.
So you could very well either have someone, an insider threat that works for the telco
or a nation state actor.
I'm aware of multiple cases of each.
Can't go into them for NDAs, obviously, but I'm aware of multiple cases where these networks
are being targeted and the enterprises accidentally find out about it.
And like one organization, they called some IP addresses out of an interesting part of
the world coming in from their MPLS VPN is secure.
It's secure because it's VPN, right?
There is from their public, private, rather their private VPN service, there is traffic
exfiltrating out their firewall and they didn't recognize the IP addresses and they tracked
it back and the telco MPLS VPN network had been hacked and some adversary had added themselves
to their MPLS VPN.
And then of course, there's a lot of conversations on the internet about BGP hacking.
I want to throw out the idea that one way to detect this, if you don't have good visibility
is timing.
Even if you're on the enterprise side, if you're out on the edge of a telecommunications
carrier network, you're not sure what's happening with the telco.
You can't hide from physics and time is going to tell the truth.
If you've got a baseline of what your connectivity looks like to your remote locations, you know,
say across Poland, across Europe, Asia, the US, South America, the Pacific, et cetera.
If you have a good baseline of that, you can be able to go and indicate that someone
is doing like using MPLS traffic engineering or something to redirect your traffic down
a different path so that they can do capture or possibly injection into your MPLS network
or your internet network.
There's something else to consider and there's a bunch of papers out there on this.
One thing I want to draw your attention to is there's a big push to put lots of technology
out on the military now, both in the US and, of course, here in Europe.
Everyone is deploying and adding new technology and putting all these specialized sensors
and devices on troops as well as emergency responders, adding all kinds of new gadgets
and communications devices, but as IT and cyber security professionals, we've got to
figure out how we're going to threat hunt all these devices, do the forensics and threat
hunt and monitor the local system on an emergency responder or a military personnel.
How do we monitor and make sure those devices are not being hacked, that there's some kind
of compromise to them with the whole military things and battlefield things?
One thing to consider is leveraging software-defined radio to monitor all these different protocols
that may be getting utilized, like LORA and LORAWAN and all the different SATCOM communications,
something that a lot of people are not thinking about.
What about the ham radio protocol?
It's low speed, not a lot of bandwidth, and that's an old-school protocol that more seasoned
professionals are aware of the ham networks and ham protocols, and a lot of the younger
generation that are coming up are not aware of the ham networks and don't use it because
it's too slow for them, and they're not interested in having voice communications over ham, but
the ham radio network has the ability to do data communication, and it's not going
to be high-speed.
You're not going to be X-filling terabytes of data, but you could be using it for command
control.
All you need is a shell, right?
What is to stop someone from taking that slow ham link and using it for backdoor data communications
or for command control?
Something else to look at, and also keep an eye on this 5G and 6G, and 6G, I mean, everybody's
talking about it.
It's coming with the new satellite architectures that are about to be deployed.
Something else to put on your radar, if it ain't already, is the whole internet of space
things.
SpaceX bought a company called Swarm, and what they're doing is putting in satellites
in very low-Earth orbit.
In very low-Earth orbit, those satellites are not going to stay up in orbit for very
long because of the atmospheric drag.
Because atmospheric drag, it's going to pull those satellites out of orbit, and they're
going to burn up in the atmosphere after being up there for a short period of time, so it's
not going to be a big issue with debris, things like that, because where they're located in
orbit, they'll just fall out and burn out, and they're small.
But we need to be thinking about in our plans of how are we going to do forensics and incident
response and threat hunting of all these low-Earth wind devices.
It's another communication protocol, a whole other set of devices, and I'm having a lot
of conversations around these type of devices and looking at using these communications,
and so as threat hunters, we need to be thinking about how we're going to go and hunt lower
wind and these type of IOT devices.
Last year, I was here, I spoke about some of the satellites that have been hacked, and
I'll just hit this real fast.
The Landsat 7 was hacked a couple times, it was confirmed it was attacked, the Terra
satellite was targeted, that was confirmed to be an attack, be taken over momentarily,
there was a NOAA satellite, NOAA is an organization in the U.S., it monitors the atmosphere, the
oceans and things for the U.S., that satellite was attacked successfully, and then control
was regained from it.
There's debate about the ROSAT, depending on what camp you're in, there's those that
say it wasn't hacked, and they will argue behemothly that it was not hacked, then there's
others that say that it really was hacked and it was directed toward the sun and burned
up the sensor and disabled that satellite.
The speculation on the ROSAT is that a ground station was hacked in Europe, I think it was
by the Russians, is what the speculation is, it was hacked and the satellite was turned,
and so it was disabled.
Then the UK Skynet satellite, that's one of, Skynet is a UK military satellite network,
it's a constellation of four satellites, there's a lot of arguing back and forth about whether
that really got hacked or not.
I found some pretty good references that said that they didn't admit that the whole satellite
was totally taken care of, hacked, and held for ransom, but I did find references that
said that admitted that the control link was taken control of momentarily, so me, I read
it got hacked, but depending on what camp you're in, the argument goes back and forth
whether it happened, but I did find links where it was admitted that the control link
was successfully targeted, so we've got to be thinking about threat hunting these satellites
and things, and so from a cybersecurity threat hunting standpoint, what are we up against?
From a legacy standpoint, what I've been able to find is 23 different space operating systems
that have been used, there's probably more that I have not been able to identify yet.
A brand new one that I just discovered down at the bottom in the center is MIT's come
out with a new cyber-hardened satellite software system where they've gone in and engineered
from the ground up for that operating system for a spacecraft to be secure from the very
beginning, so that's a new operating system, it was just published, I don't know if it's
going to be available in the open source like on GitHub or if it's only going to be select
organizations that have access to it, I have no idea yet, but most of the satellites today
that are being flown are predominantly Linux-based kernels, like SpaceX, SpaceX has its own Linux
kernel for the rockets and its satellite systems, they have a hardened Linux kernel, so most
things are converging on a custom Linux kernel, but if we're going to, like I said, if we're
going to go start doing threat hunting, we're working for some organization that's got space
craft assets, we've got to account for this, how we're going to go and do threat hunting,
forensics, incident response in space.
Then when, also we start looking at this, then there's not only the operating system,
but the command languages to talk to the spacecraft, because a lot of them are more of, a lot of
the new ones are using Linux, Python is probably going to be an option, the CCSDS standard
is probably what you're going to see primarily as a command language on most of these satellites.
It's an international standard, a lot of the satellites use, but you need to be aware of
these other command languages, depending on the satellites that you're, there's a lot
of satellites that are, that have been in orbit for a long time, legacy satellites that
we may have to deal with and have to go and be able to do threat hunting against.
And along, and also along that same line are the protocols that the satellites might be using.
Predominantly, you're going to see the CCSDS space communication protocol, that is an international
standard, and also in Europe, there is the European Cooperation for Space Standardization
Packet Utilization Standard, ECSS, that is a protocol that is a standard that's used
for a lot of satellites here in Europe that you may run into, but there is a, but there
are a lot of protocols out there that you could encounter if you started working for
an organization that has spacecraft assets that you need to help get monitoring visibility
on.
And of course, IP and IPv6 are out there, and we have WebOne, SpaceX, with the Starlink
network, and Biosat, they're all running IP, and MPLS and all that.
So where are we at from a cybersecurity standpoint in space?
This is, I'm an old school Cisco guy, that's what I grew up, spent most of my career working
on Cisco routers and networking.
So this really got my attention because I remember back when Cisco self-defending networks
came out in the early 2000s, so their first intrusion prevention system came out from
a company that I believe is called NetRanger, I believe they had the very first one, Cisco
bought them, and now everybody's got an intrusion prevention system.
But Slingshot is a satellite that the Aerospace Corporation put up in September of 2022, and
it has an intrusion prevention system capability on it, and so it's constantly monitoring and
logging and looking for unexpected commands, commands out of order.
It's baselining all the data that's coming into it, any kind of commands that are out
of line of what's expected, it's utilizing machine learning to detect anomalies in activity
on the spacecraft itself, and any commands that are sent to it.
I think this is pretty interesting that where things are headed with a self-defending satellite.
We've had the self-defending networks where a firewall IDS can detect an attack, and then
the firewall IDS can reconfigure, it can reconfigure the firewall in your router to respond to
that attack.
Well, now we're looking at using that same kind of concept for a satellite so that the
satellite can defend itself, which is here in Europe, a satellite was launched in July
of 2021, and similarly, it has a self-defending capability, and it's using software-defined
radio so that if it starts detecting and someone messing with its frequencies, trying to jam
the satellite, it's using the same frequencies interfering with it, the satellite, the software-defined
radio on the satellite can be reprogrammed dynamically to defend itself and jump to different
frequencies so that it can keep operating and work through whether it's accidental or
intentional disruption to its communications.
I think it's really interesting to see where this is going to go.
I'm really fascinated with the possibilities of a self-defending spacecraft.
Here are some tools that are new.
Everybody knows about MITRE ATT&CK.
All through this presentation, we talked about machine learning and AI over and over again.
So if you're interested in machine learning and AI, you also need to be looking at MITRE
ATLAS because the machine learning AI are being targeted with what's called adversarial
machine learning, where the machine learning and AI algorithms and the data are being targeted.
So you want to go and check out MITRE ATLAS if you're involved with machine learning projects
because your machine learning AI is going to be targeted as well.
The European Space Agency, just here a couple weeks ago, released SHIELD.
Think of SHIELD as a space capability similar to MITRE ATT&CK, but it came out of the European
Space Agency.
It's brand new.
There's SPARTA.
It's similar to MITRE ATT&CK, but it came out of Aerospace Corporation.
I had a good friend of mine, Dr. Jacob Oakley.
He just released this framework called TREX.
I encourage you to look at that.
That's focused on space vehicles.
Dr. Oakley is a true SME in cybersecurity, and he actually wrote the only book that I'm aware of on
space cybersecurity.
So if you're interested in space satellite cybersecurity, you need to check out Dr. Oakley's
book out on Amazon.
It's a really good book.
And also, a new tool that I'm interested in that also has industrial control system plug-ins is
MITRE's Caldera, which will help automate some of these frameworks for both blue team and red
team testing.
We'll make sure those are on your radar.
